displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.” Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from?

Family Member: So he’ll go downstairs and get his blood drawn. Doctor: Yes. All right. So let me make a copy of this though for you for your records. Family Member: We’re very thankful for meeting you. And how thorough you are. And how comfortable, you make you know, it makes me feel comfortable. Doctor: Thank you. Thank you. I always tell me I'm not happy that we met under the circumstances- Patient: Yes. Doctor: - but try make the best of it. Family Member: Yes, yes. And your knowledge you know. You have so much knowledge, you know, different trials and medicines Doctor: You'll help me, you know my family is not in medicine. Family Member: Oh really? Doctor: But sometimes I get accused of speaking in too much medical lingo. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So if you don't, because a lot of my friends are doctors obviously.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Patient: da Vinci procedure, da Vinci procedure. Doctor: Look at you. Get you on the table just like that. (laughs) Patient: da Vinci procedure (makes whistle noise) Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Snip, snip, snip, bzzz. (makes various noises) Doctor: See that. You’re Patient: Been there, done that. Doctor: I know… Patient: Been there done that, so it’s… Doctor: We might come around to that. Who knows. It’s twenty-seventeen right? Patient: That’s… That’s right. Doctor: It would be nice to get. The other, the other part…

Patient: Push, just push Doctor: Yes. Pull up towards me. (Paper rattling and thumping) Patient: Yeah, no, like I said, at work, I don’t have any problem with walking around, but since, I say, I noticed that I was gettin’ that pain, and it was startin’ to become an irritant to me where I used to didn’t have that problem. You know? Doctor: Now, are you using anything for pain? Patient: No. I didn’t want to do that until I talked to you. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to give you a prescription? Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more.

Family Member: And to report that you got back. Doctor: Yeah, they didn’t have that perspective. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They were just busy measuring just for the sake of studying and seeing what Family Member: This way it keeps Doctor: Exactly, yeah. They weren’t looking at what’s closer; that was not in there, factored into their thinking about what treatment impact it would have. Patient: Well, you know it’s kind uh; it’s hard to understand. Doctor: I agree. Patient: I accept that. You know it’s uh- Healthcare Professional: He did say his back pain was great the day after the injection but it’s back again. Doctor: It’s back? Family Member: Uh hum. Patient: I, yeah, I -

Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm. Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been?

Patient: Mm, Hmm. Doctor: There’s only one, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue, okay. Doctor: Then less common there’s a whole bunch of them. Patient: Right. Doctor: Back pain, diarrhea, flashes, edema. So it’s everything that you had last… Patient: Doc, Doc, Doc, that’s another thing. Doctor: What? Patient: I ain’t going to the bathroom regularly and started taking my stool softeners and then I’m mixing up the what-ya-call-it too. Doctor: Yep, that’s what you gotta do. You want me to put this here? I just gave him the side effect sheet. Patient: I need. Family Member: I was gonna look them up anyway.

Patient: trying to do the best I can health wise and… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …and uh uh as far as uh you know relationship-wise uh I I you know I meet people you know ladies and they get to like me, but they won’t to another step then it just seems like my physical part down there they’re trying to come in but they won’t. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so.. Doctor: Alright. It takes up to a year Patient: I’m still having problems. Doctor: It takes a year generally and your surgery was when August? Patient: Uhh September. Doctor: September and so do you have any flows at all? Patient: Uh no you know it acting like it wanna but never… Doctor: And you’re taking the medicine?

Family Member: Like internal? Doctor: -but the whole idea of this closed monitoring is to not let it get that far. But you know obviously if you notice any bleeding, nose bleeds, gum bleeds, blood in the urine, whatever I need to know right away. Family Member: But how about the bleeding that’s rectal bleeding that he’s having now. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so has you know we’ll probably have to wait and see, but changes are that should respond to just medical management and will clear up. Family Member: Yeah and you know we had the colonoscopy and the… Doctor: Yeah Family Member: …and they cauterized. Doctor: the radiation and it’s cauterized now so I’m thinking that will take care of it. Patient: Yet no polyps, no polyps. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, good. Healthcare Professional: And their advice to hold up on aspirin. Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-? Doctor: It’s supposed to be but I think the question is you know for the extra twenty or thirty thousand dollars that it costs- Family Member: Um Hmm. Doctor: -is that truly better than what the regulation radiation is going to afford because it’s not the old time radiation. The radiation you got is still image guided. It’s still blocked off. So those studies are ongoing. And that’s why not every center and not every state has protons. Because the cost is just astronomical- Family Member: Really. Doctor: -and not every insurance company is really paying for it. And you don’t know if it’s better. So this issue comes around a lot because of prostate. So protons wanted to replace, you know, oh, and I going to save the bladder or anything else. And that data doesn’t show it to be better necessarily. So it’s a big fight between the radiation guys. They’re trying to figure that out themselves. Um, but I don’t know. I think it’s good technology. So I think if needed, if it was a really tough spot or really small area I think it’s reasonable. But you had many spots that the radiation had to go after so I’m not sure that much of an advantage would have been gained. Patient: Well this radiation I went through this time-

Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I understand the, you know I, I, I you know basically I said if I have a mass… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …that’s to me a target, if I have a target. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and if I’m at the range with my Glock seventeen…

Patient: Okay. I like that. Doctor: Yeah, so we have a plan either Patient: Okay. Doctor: way and I’ll, you know, continue to sort of work through this Patient: Okay. Doctor: . Now, in the meantime, I don’t like you in pain and I think that having a small dose of narcotics like Norco Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do.

Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours. Doctor: hm mmm, yep, yeah, Do you feel like you empty when you pee Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or do you feel there’s a little more in there? Patient: There’s more because you go ahead and pee the full stream then you stop then you, it’s bogged down. Doctor: Yep, Yep, So, do me a favor. Like after seven p.m. at night don’t drink fluid; Patient: Okay. Doctor: don’t drink water, don’t drink tea, don’t drink coffee, don’t drink juice, don’t drink milk, don’t drink anything. After dinner, just done. One, that will allow you to sleep because I think your prostate is acting up, it’s too big which means it’s blocking the way of the pee and then what happens is you pee but there’s stuff left over but your body doesn’t know it until just a little bit more accumulates in there and also your bladder is like oh, I was this full and now I’m this full, okay, I got to pee again and when you’re laying down you pee a lot easier because then your whole body is trying to recalibrate and what’s happening. So, at that point you got to pee some more. So, if you give it less reason to pee which means you don’t have enough fluid on board then you won’t pee because there’s not fluid to put through. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you do me a favor and do that. I’ll work on getting your CAT scan and your bone scan set up and then we’ll figure out the next step. My thinking is that it probably - I’m going to shoot for the ah vaccine because once that’s done we don’t go back to it and then we just sort of put that and say done and then we move on to the other stuff. What do you think of that? Because if that sounds okay what takes forever is insurance Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: so if you’re kind of conceptually okay with that then I’m going to have J____, you know J____ who is our nurse, if you don’t know J____, you’re gonna know J____ in a minute. Patient: Is that the one that took the…

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
